title: Why can't I be responsible? - Quora

response.answer_text: We are always a result of the mix of our beliefs and we rank our beliefs in order of the passion/depth of the belief. So they exist in layers inside of us with “I don’t want to die” at or near the top and “I like vanilla” closer to the bottom. So…like in a game of poker, you (maybe unknowingly) shared some of your beliefs with us. Therefore, if you want to be responsible, that would need to rise up higher (more passion/depth) as a belief than it is now. We all have untested head affirmation type “beliefs” like world peace, end hunger, reverse global warming, “being a good person”, etc.. But in general, these are never tested in a high personal stress situation….like maybe losing your job, losing your friends, losing your home/apartment, losing your car, etc.. Most are “going along to get along” type pf cultural affirmations. I suspect your “being responsible” might be one of those head affirmations (maybe peer induced). But no matter the reason, you won’t change unless your personal costs/sufferings to remain irresponsible rise up much higher and are higher than the costs/sufferings to change and be responsible. Without that “test”, it’ll likely remain a head affirmation. I’m 72 and at 18 in college I had a close call with me committing suicide. That “rearranged” my priorities. I had been an increasingly skilled thief and liar in high school and this wake up call (test) pushed Virtue way up high on my belief priority list…..to the top, actually. Before that it was a yadda yadda yadda head affirmation only. Hope this helps.

Okay … for starters, scratch the “Why.” I suspect your real question is “What can I do about my irresponsibility?” You’ve asked the question, which is an excellent start! Know that everyone occasionally shirks responsibility. “I don’t know!” “It wasn’t me!” But you do know. It was you. So you start by admitting, at least to yourself, that you were responsible, and that you have to “fix” the problem. You mop up the spilled paint without admitting responsibility. You do everything you can to ease the hurt. You do not walk away from the consequences, whether you admit responsibility, or not. That’s step two. Then, you don’t make that mistake again. You accept the responsibility for making sure the paint is properly stored, or the door is locked or the water’s turned off—whatever it is. Eventually, you’ll probably want to own up to your errors. “Confession” really is “good for the soul.” And you’ll find that it frequently makes it much easier to fix the problem and learn from it. In summary, then: Know you’re (at least occasionally) irresponsible—CHECK!Do everything you can to fix the problem, even if you don’t admit it was your fault.Figure out what you did (or didn’t do) that caused the problem and don’t make that mistake again.Own up to your mistakes. It will make things easier, in the long run.I hope this helps!
